Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix for the Gallery unable to find license file if paths with backslashes are used" (#6739) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6737.

Per zip file format [specification](http://www.pkware.com/documents/casestudies/APPNOTE.TXT) (4.4.17.1), only forward slashes can be used in paths inside zip file, but paths in nuspec can contain both forward and back slashes. So added code that fixes the paths before they are passed into `PackageArchiveReader`.

On the other hand, `ZipArchive` implementation in .net does not enforce forward slashes and allows to create zip files with backslashes in paths, so alternative pack implementations might exist that produce technically invalid zip files, not sure we want to support those though.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "License file package - License info should appear only after validation job and redirect to correct Url. " (#6738) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
License info link for package with license file should appear only after validation job, and it should redirect to the correct Url in Gallery.
Fix: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6734

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Licenses] Gallery is sensitive to path separator type used in license file paths" (#6737) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: `<license type="file">license\license.txt</license>` vs `<license type="file">license/license.txt</license>`. Both cases pack fine, bit the first one is rejected by Gallery. We need to support both.

Events.RelatedBody:
Is there a way to resolve this dependency?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Edge and Firefox try to download license files with content type "text/markdown"" (#6735) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
If package has an embedded license file ".md" extension, it gets saved to flatcontainer with "text/markdown" content type. When both Edge and Firefox browsers are pointed to those files, they prompt to save it instead of displaying it. Chrome displays those.
Need to have consistent behavior.
Making everything to be `text/plain` works, but we lose the type information for blobs (we still have an indication in DB though, so not a big deal for Gallery).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "License info link on gallery is not correct for license type=file" (#6734) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
While validating, it should be a "Not yet available" warning or perhaps not even be there.

After validating, it should link to a page where I can see the license file.

Today, it just links to the deprecation URL in both cases.

/cc @zhhyu @agr

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The place for enhancement requests, and the feature to follow/unfollow a package?" (#6733) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Nuget should provide a place for customers to keep enhancement requests. Current issue tracker may not be the correct place. 
Nuget.org should also provide the feature so that customers could follow/unfollow a package so customers could keep track of a package and have a favorites list.
The visual studio feedback area may be a similar feature.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Increase API rate limit" (#6732) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Now it's 250 packages/hour. Given our perf improvements, we can increase to 350 per hour.

Should also update documentation:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Install the.NetFramework packages in .NetCore projects" (#7602) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi Everyone,

I have generated the custom NuGet package for our assemblies with some dependent NuGet packages. 

NuGet package lib folder structure:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16695209/49623870-6a44d600-f9f5-11e8-8f48-4a1795d26e25.png)

Dependent NuGet package lib folder structure:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16695209/49623997-d7f10200-f9f5-11e8-81d6-d8db647f5b4a.png)

Now I have tried to install my custom NuGet package in .NETCORE projects. Packages installed successfully. But assembly not referred like I expected.

.NetFramework assembly structure - 2.4{Frameworkversion}.0.2 (For Ex: 2.4450.0.2)
.NetCore assembly structure - 2.4.0.2

I expect the assemblies like .Netframework structure in core project. Parent package assemblies added as i expected but, dependent packages assemblies added like .netcore assembly structure. But I need to add the .netframework assemblies structure from the dependent NuGet packages.

Could you please suggest me to achieve this?

Thanks,
Ganesan R.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "License file with no extension fails to pack with dotnet pack and msbuild /t:pack" (#7601) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): dotnet.exe and msbuild.exe

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.1.600-preview-009426
msbuild version: 16.0.218-preview+g5c625fa747

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

* `dotnet new classlib`
* edit generated csproj, add the following lines:
```
  <PropertyGroup>
    <PackageLicenseFile>license</PackageLicenseFile>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <None Include="license" Pack="true" PackagePath="$(PackageLicenseFile)" />
  </ItemGroup>
```
* Create the `license` file with any text
* `dotnet pack`

### Verbose Logs
```
> dotnet pack
Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 16.0.225-preview+g5ebeba52a1 for .NET Core
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

  Restore completed in 39.19 ms for E:\dev\misc\libtest3\libtest3.csproj.
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.600-preview-009426\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\targets\Microsoft.NET.RuntimeIdentifierInference.targets(143,5): message NETSDK1057: You are working with a preview version of the .NET Core SDK. You can define the SDK version via a global.json file in the current project. More at https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=869452 [E:\dev\misc\libtest3\libtest3.csproj]
  libtest3 -> E:\dev\misc\libtest3\bin\Debug\netstandard2.0\libtest3.dll
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.600-preview-009426\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error NU5030: The license file 'license' does not exist in the package. [E:\dev\misc\libtest3\libtest3.csproj]
```

### Other
If I remove the `<PackageLicenseFile>license</PackageLicenseFile>` line, it packs fine and `license` file is added to nupkg. It also works if I drop the `PackagePath="$(PackageLicenseFile)"` portion.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Packages.lock.json causes spurious 'dotnet restore' errors when using a nuget-based MSBuild project sdk" (#7599) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

dotnet.exe --version: 2.2.100

Suppose I have a project P that uses nuget sdk N and N has never been installed on the machine again.

If P does not contain a packages.lock.json file, `dotnet restore --use-lock-file` will succeed.
If P *does* have a lock file, `dotnet restore --use-lock-file` will print errors the first time, then succeed on subsequent runs

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Unzip [lockFile_spuriousError_repro.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2655378/lockFile_spuriousError_repro.zip) somewhere on your machine.

2. Run repro.bat

...

After debugging through the code a bit, the issue comes to a head in `ValidatePackagesSha512(PackagesLockFile lockFile, LockFile assetsFile)`. The method effectively checks that all the hashes in the in-memory assets.json object match those in the lock file. This normally works fine since the sdk packages aren't actually written to either file. However, in the degenerate case, the SDK package appears in `assetsFile` for some reason (though the sdk package is never included in the generated file). In this case, the error is produced since `lockFile` has no corresponding hash.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "In VS, the "Pack" option in project context menu no-ops if build no-ops" (#7598) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Found in VS 15.9.4 Preview 1.0. NuGet version 4.9.2.5706.

## Steps to repro

1. Create new .NET Core class library
2. Build solution
3. Right click on project
4. Click "Pack"

## Expected

The .nupkg should be produced.

## Actual

The build no-ops and no package is produced.

```
========== Build: 0 succeeded, 0 failed, 1 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========
```

## Workaround

Clean the project then pack.

```
1>------ Build started: Project: ClassLibrary1, Configuration: Debug Any CPU ------
1>ClassLibrary1 -> D:\trash\2018-12-06\ClassLibrary1\ClassLibrary1\bin\Debug\netcoreapp2.1\ClassLibrary1.dll
1>Successfully created package 'D:\trash\2018-12-06\ClassLibrary1\ClassLibrary1\bin\Debug\ClassLibraryUber.1.0.1.nupkg'.
========== Build: 1 succeeded, 0 failed, 0 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add dependencies for multiple frameworks in NuSpec file" (#7597) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@p0onage commented on [Wed Dec 05 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/1206)

I've created a Nuget package from a project targetting .Net Standard 2.0 but when coming to install this project from the Nuget feed it is not visible within a .Net framework 4.7 solution. The reason for the is having .Net Standard 2.0 as a dependency. 

I fixed this in the end by using 
`  <TargetFrameworks>netstandard2.0;net47</TargetFrameworks>`
but it would have been ideal if the NuSpec file has an override dependency area where I could remove this dependency and state any other dependencies. We have a Dependencies field in the metadata of the nuspec file but it doesn't work as expected

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Restore unnecessarily enumerates global packages cache directory in attempt to determine type" (#7596) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Nuget version 4.9.0.6

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a packages.config file like the following
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<packages>
  <package id="protobuf-net" version="2.1.0" />
</packages>
```
2. Open procmon and filter to accesses by nuget.exe

3. 'nuget restore <path to packages.config>

4. Notice that procmon has recorded a directory enumeration in an unrelated subdirectory of the global packages cache

This is caused by the fact that Nuget internally 'forgets' the feed type for the packages cache and needs to look at the file system to determine if it's e.g. v2 or v3.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Infinite loop in ConcurrencyUtilities.ExecuteWithFileLockedAsync" (#7530) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When restoring a project in a destination path longer than MAX_PATH, the lock utilities enter an infinite loop. We expect the restore to fail immediately with PathTooLongException.
NuGet.Commands 4.8.
